Award.AwardTitle: URM: The watershed as a model for improving minority, graduate student success in Biology.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Buffalo State College's URM program will recruit nine undergraduate students each year for four years and provide them with research and training experiences to succeed in graduate school in the biological sciences, with special emphasis in aquatic biology. The goals of this URM project are to increase undergraduate diversity representation in, and post-baccalaureate success of, biology majors. Eleven faculty members from four departments will provide mentoring support and expertise within our theme of understanding aquatic-terrestrial linkages in mixed-use watersheds". Two key facilities, the Buffalo State Great Lakes Field Station near the intersection of Lake Erie and the Buffalo and Niagara Rivers, and the Point Peter Brook instrumented watershed, will allow us to use a paired watershed approach to investigate drivers of change. Students will be recruited into the program as juniors. The students and their faculty mentors will populate a new Watershed Institute and participate in a 2-year research experience. Major activities of student participants include a week-long watershed assessment workshop held at biological field station, intensive field experience aboard the R\V Aquarius, a 3-course sequence, and travel to and presentation of research results at regional and national conferences. The courses will provide training in career exploration, biostatistics and experimental design, GRE preparation, writing and communication. All of the faculty mentors have prior experience with underrepresented minority students and have or are currently conducting research within our target watersheds. More information is available at http://www.buffalostate.edu/ biology/urm.xml.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

This URM project provided training and research opportunities in watershed and aquatic biology for 12 undergraduate students from Buffalo State College. Student majors included Biology, Geography & Planning, and Chemistry. Demographics of this students group included eight females and 4 males, of which three were African American (25%), two were Native American or mixed Native decent (16.7%), one was Hispanic/Latino (8.3%), and six were of European decent (50%). This represents a strongly divergent demographic from the base student pool at BSC. Seven of the 12 students are currently still undergraduates. Of the five graduates, four are either in graduate programs or professional degree options in their field. Collectively, these students contributed research presentations and peer-reviewed publications on topics as diverse as invasive species ecology, parasites of invasive mussels, water quality in wetland in urban landscapes, fish fatty acid metabolism, swimming beach bacteria populations, soil nutrient dynamics in restored urban landscapes, nutrient stoichiometry in mussels of an urban river, and macroinvertebrates within leafpack habitats in streams with and without
invasive fish species. An important lesson learned from the logistics of this
program was research careers need early mentoring and opportunity. This program was initiated to attract late career undergraduates (i.e., juniors) to prepare them for entry into graduate schools. The program did not have a large enough recruitment pool to populate it with graduate-school bound students with interests in the program topic area. The program benefitted from seeking students earlier in their post-secondary careers (e.g., sophomores). The tradeoff in accepting younger students relative to older ones was an increase in the student default rate (e.g., students that just stopped attending sessions and were subsequently dropped from the Program). The program disseminated results through peer-reviewed publications (2 student papers), presentations at regional or national meetings (18 presentations), an annual on-campus open house, and a URM website.
